//test list
Serum Creatinine Test
Bilirubin Blood Test
Complete Cholesterol Test (Lipid Panel / Lipid Profile)
ALT / SGPT (Blood)
AST / SGOT
Uric acid test
ESR
Urine Routine Examination
//Serum Creatinine
A creatinine blood test measures the level of creatinine in the blood.It helps to determine kidney diseases and provides doctor with information about how the kidneys are working.
i. Male: From 0.7 to 1.3 mg/dL\nii. Female: From 0.6 to 1.1 mg/dL
i. A blocked urinary tract\n ii. A high-protein diet\n iii. Dehydration\n iv. Kidney problems, such as kidney damage or infection\n v. Reduced blood flow to the kidneys due to shock, congestive heart failure, or complications of diabetes\n
//Bilirubin
Helps to determine the cause of Jaundice, also helps diagnose conditions like liver disease, hemolytic anemia, and blocked bile ducts.
i. Direct bilirubin: 0 to 0.4 mg/DL (milligrams per deciliter)\nii. Total bilirubin: 0.3 to 1.0 mg/DL (milligrams per deciliter)
Causes of abnormal bilirubin level: High bilirubin level may be due to,\n i. Jaundice.\n ii. Problems with the liver.\n iii.Problems with Bile ducts.\n iv. Problems with Gallbladder.\n
//Complete cholesterol
A complete cholesterol test helps doctor to measure the amount of “good” and “bad” cholesterol and triglycerides, a type of fat, in patient’s blood. It helps to determine possibilities of,\n i. Heart disease\n ii. Stroke\n iii. Atherosclerosis, a clogging or hardening of your arteries
i. LDL (Low-density lipoprotein): 70 to 130 mg/dL (the lower the number, the better)\n ii. HDL (High-density lipoprotein): more than 40 to 60 mg/dL (the higher the number, the better)\n iii. total cholesterol: less than 200 mg/dL (the lower the number, the better)\n iv. triglycerides: 10 to 150 mg/dL (the lower the number, the better)\n
//ALT or SGPT
The ALT or SGPT test is usually used to determine whether the patient has liver injury or failure.
Normal value of ALT test: The normal value for ALT in blood is between 7 and 55 units per liter.
Higher-than-normal levels of ALT can indicate liver damage. Increased levels of ALT may be a result of:\n i. hepatitis, which is an inflammatory condition of the liver\n ii. cirrhosis, which is severe scarring of the liver\n iii. death of liver tissue\n iv. a tumor or cancer in the liver\n v. a lack of blood flow to the liver\n vi. hemochromatosis, which is a disorder that causes iron to build up in the body\n vii. mononucleosis, which is an infection usually caused by the Epstein-Barr virus\n viii. pancreatitis, which is an inflammation of the pancreas\n
//AST or SGOT
AST test is commonly performed to check for liver diseases, such as hepatitis. It’s usually measured together with alanine aminotransferase (ALT). The AST-to-ALT ratio can help your doctor diagnose liver disease. This ratio can determine if there’s been damage to your liver as opposed to damage to your heart or muscles.
Typically the range for normal AST is reported between 10 to 40 units per liter.\n
//Uric Acid
A uric acid blood test, also known as a serum uric acid measurement, determines how much uric acid is present in your blood. The test can help determine how well your body produces and removes uric acid.
Uric acid levels can vary based on sex. Normal values for women are 2.5 to 7.5 milligrams/deciliter (mg/dL) and for men 4.0 to 8.5 mg/dL. However, the values may vary based on the lab doing the testing.
According to the American College of Rheumatology (ACR), your target level if you have gout is a blood uric acid level of less than 6.0 mg/dL. Low levels of uric acid are less common than high levels and are less of a health concern.\n
//ESR
It is a test that helps check for the presence of a disease, infection or condition in the body that may be causing inflammation. Though, it does not directly help in diagnosing a particular condition, it helps physicians know what other tests may be needed to detect the actual problem. It’s also a way to examine how well a person is doing to a specific treatment for a disease he/she is being treated.
Typically, an ESR test results are measured in millimetres per hour (mm/hr). Normal range of ESR Blood Test is as follows:-\n\n I. Men below the age of 50 must have an ESR rate under 15 mm/hr.\n II. Women below the age of 50 must have an ESR rate under 20 mm/hr.\n III. Men above the age of 50 must have an ESR under 20 mm/hr.\n IV. Women above the age of 50 must have an ESR under 30 mm/hr.\n V. Newborns must have an ESR under 2 mm/hr.\n VI. Children who are yet to achieve puberty must have an ESR between 2 to 13 mm/hr.\n
//Urine Routin Examination
Sample will be kept it in conditions where microorganisms can multiply. Normally, no more than a small number of germs will be in the urine if there is no infection. If a larger number of germs are present, the technician will use a microscope or chemical tests to determine the specific types growing in the culture.
Normal values are as follows:\n > Color – Yellow (light/pale to dark/deep amber)\n > Clarity/turbidity – Clear or cloudy\n > pH – 4.5-8\n > Specific gravity – 1.005-1.025\n > Glucose - ≤130 mg/d\n > Ketones – None\n > Nitrites – Negative\n > Leukocyte esterase – Negative\n > Bilirubin – Negative\n > Urobilirubin – Small amount (0.5-1 mg/dL)\n > Blood - ≤3 RBCs\n > Protein - ≤150 mg/d\n > RBCs - ≤2 RBCs/hpf\n > WBCs - ≤2-5 WBCs/hpf\n > Squamous epithelial cells - ≤15-20 squamous epithelial cells/hpf\n > Casts – 0-5 hyaline casts/lpf\n > Crystals – Occasionally\n > Bacteria – None\n > Yeast - None\n
